title: Once a Leading Polluter, the U.K. Is Now Trying to Lead on Climate Change
content: On the eve of a global climate summit, Britain’s evolution from fossil fuels to clean energy is on display. But experts question whether its commitment is sufficient, and whether it can persuade other nations to meet meaningful goals.

des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

title: Rivals on World Stage, Russia and U.S. Quietly Seek Areas of Accord
content: There have been a series of beneath-the-surface meetings between the two countries as the Biden administration applies a more sober approach to relations with the Kremlin.

more_info.byline: By Anton Troianovski and David E. Sanger
des_facet: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

title: U.K. Police Struggle to Curb Abuse of Women by Their Own Officers
content: Sexual misconduct by police officers has prompted outrage across Britain and led to increasing skepticism that departments can investigate or discipline employees who abuse women.

title: Japan’s Election Was Closer Than Usual, Even Though Party in Power Has Hit Snooze
content: The governing Liberal Democrats won on Sunday, despite having chosen a prime minister, Fumio Kishida, who’s known for his lack of charisma.

more_info.byline: By Motoko Rich, Hisako Ueno and Makiko Inoue

title: New Zealand Held a Contest for Bird of the Year. The Birds Lost.
content: The long-tailed bat, one of the country’s only two native land mammals, flew away with the top prize.

title: He Brokered Apartheid’s End. Can He Save South Africa’s Liberation Party?
content: President Cyril Ramaphosa ascended to office on a reputation as a great negotiator and consensus builder. Now he must convince voters to stick with the party of Nelson Mandela.

more_info.byline: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel

title: A South African Town Lacks Water and Electricity. But Mayors? It Has Two.
content: Dysfunctional and collapsing rural towns may test voters’ loyalty to the ruling African National Congress party in nationwide municipal elections on Monday.

title: Biden Finds Raising Corporate Tax Rates Easier Abroad Than at Home
content: As the Group of 20 seals a new global minimum tax for companies, the president has scaled back his plans to tax U.S. corporations more.

more_info.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
org_facet: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

title: Protesters Killed in Sudan on Day Seen as a Test for the Military
content: Three demonstrators were fatally shot, a doctors’ group said, as crowds answered activists’ call for a “march of millions” against a coup that has threatened the country’s democratic transition.

des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

title: Xi Hasn’t Left China in 21 Months. Covid May Be Only Part of the Reason.
content: Xi Jinping’s lack of face time with world leaders signals a turn inward on domestic issues and a reluctance to compromise on the global stage.

more_info.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley

title: Behind a Top Female Name in Spanish Crime Fiction: Three Men
content: Carmen Mola, a novelist publishing under a pen name, seemed to shatter a glass ceiling in the world of Spanish books. But when the author’s true identity was revealed while claiming a big prize, it was a shock.

title: An Electricity Crisis Complicates the Climate Crisis in Europe
content: Prices for power have soared, and some politicians are now trying to use that as a lever to slow action on climate change, a strategy with far-reaching consequences.

more_info.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Somini Sengupta

title: ‘They Lied.’ Inside the Frantic Days Leading to Sudan’s Coup
content: The American envoy, Jeffrey Feltman, was given assurances that seemed to head off a military takeover. Hours later, Lt. Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan made his move.

more_info.byline: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Declan Walsh

title: What Is Day of the Dead, the Mexican Holiday?
content: Popularized by Hollywood in films like “Coco” and the James Bond franchise, Día de Muertos is a centuries-old tradition that has roots in Indigenous culture.

title: What to watch for on Monday at COP26.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson will welcome leaders, who will then lay out “concrete actions and credible plans.” David Attenborough and Prince Charles will also speak.

title: Australians allowed to return home as strict border rules ease.
content: The government lifted restrictions on citizens and permanent residents seeking to return to the country. Australians no longer need to obtain an exemption to leave.

title: Your Monday Briefing
content: Deciding the future of the climate.

title: Struggling at Home, Biden Is Buoyed by G20 Trip Abroad
content: A trip to Rome invigorated a president whose poll numbers are slumping at home, but who projected confidence in his foreign and domestic agenda.

more_info.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Katie Rogers

title: Brazilian Police Kill 25 Accused of Planning Bank Heists
content: The police say an operation against a gang planning bank robberies killed at least 25 suspects in the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais on Sunday.

title: At Climate Talks, Biden Will Try to Sell American Leadership to Skeptics
content: The president wants to assure Glasgow’s climate summit that the U.S. is serious about climate change. But he lacks a legislative win at home.

title: Your Monday Briefing
content: Climate conference begins in Glasgow.

title: U.S. Military Jury Condemns Terrorist’s Torture and Urges Clemency
content: Seven senior officers rebuked the government’s treatment of an admitted terrorist in a handwritten letter from the jury room at Guantánamo Bay.

title: New York City firefighters are calling out sick as a vaccine mandate looms.
content: More than 22,000 municipal workers remained unvaccinated a day before a city deadline to get their first dose of a coronavirus vaccine.

more_info.byline: By Joseph Goldstein and Ashley Southall

title: The F.D.A. is assessing whether the Moderna vaccine can cause heart problems in adolescents.
content: The F.D.A. has notified Moderna that it needs more time to review the vaccine’s safety and may not deliver a decision until January.

title: G20 Nations Agree to New Limits on Coal-Burning Power Plants
content: The world’s largest economies will stop financing coal plants abroad, though that falls far short of what’s needed to fight climate change, raising fears of half-steps at this week’s U.N. summit.

more_info.byline: By Somini Sengupta, Jason Horowitz and Jim Tankersley

title: Afghan Art Flourished for 20 Years. Can It Survive the New Taliban Regime?
content: So far, the Taliban have not banned art outright. But many artists have fled Afghanistan, fearing for their work and their lives.

title: G20 leaders send a symbolic message on a key climate target.
content: Countries will “pursue efforts” to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius, compared with preindustrial times.

more_info.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Jason Horowitz

title: “Vax” is Oxford’s 2021 word of the year.
At Saudi Investment Conference, Trump Allies Remain Front and Center
content: But the Biden administration sent only a deputy commerce secretary to the high-profile gathering, amid shifts in global politics and diplomatic strains.

title: Biden receives communion at a church in Rome, a day after the pope’s blessing.
content: Some conservative bishops in the United States have said the president should be denied communion because of his support for abortion rights.

title: U.S. Agrees to Roll Back European Steel and Aluminum Tariffs
content: The deal, which comes as U.S. and E.U. allies meet in Rome, will keep some trade protections in place in a nod to metalworking unions that supported President Biden.

more_info.byline: By Ana Swanson and Katie Rogers

title: Photos from Day 1 of the summit.
content: Colorful protests outside the G20 meetings, and in them, exchanges between world leaders.

title: Gulf States Withdraw Ambassadors to Lebanon Over Criticism of Yemen War
content: With a few stray comments from a minor minister, Lebanon once again found itself caught in the rivalry between Saudi Arabia and Iran, underscoring just how vulnerable it is to the whims of its more powerful neighbors.

title: More New York City workers get Covid shots as deadline nears, but tensions remain.
content: The city’s effort to compel most city employees to receive the coronavirus vaccine before Monday appears to have rapidly boosted inoculation rates.
